item.dc:creator: gibbelin
item.description:
Gordon Freeman is 26 years old. Hugh Laurie and Gary Oldman (who’s an enormously famous and respected actor and has been since Sid and Nancy in the 80’s; not sure where the idea came from that he wasn’t) are in their 50s. Either would have been fine in their heyday, but they’re just too old for the character now.

Granted, Deniro and Pesci played versions of themselves in their 20s in Goodfellas, but it was just for a short portion of the movie and was not convincing at all.

I still think Armie Hammer would be good. He’s got the intelligence and class of someone you’d believe came from an Ivy League school, but the physicality and presence of someone who could kick all kinds of alien ass.

item.dc:creator: Shiva_KP
item.description:
Raminator:

Being a video game movie ruins video game movies.

I’m not sure this has to be true, though it’s generally been true in the past. I honestly think it might be possible to make a movie which uses the core elements of a video game as its driving force and to end up with something that has merit - in the case of Half-Life, it might be wise to start with Black Mesa, the central disaster, a scientist trapped at the heart of it (Freeman) and then work from there, not worrying too much about what the fans will think but rather worrying about what will make a good film. The problem is that the fans will almost literally froth at the mouth with rage when they actually watch it, even though - as a piece of art in its own right - it would be something worth watching rather than another confused Uwe Boll catastrophe.
